Things 're lookin' up on the docks, huh, Jackie?
Didn't you recognize him, dopey. That's Old Man Doyle.
(losing his bravado)
Doyle. (looks around at Pop, the identity hitting him)
Joey Doyle's... .? (stares at Edie)
... .You're his... .
(firmly)
Sister. Yes I am. He runs his hand over his face and then, with a sudden im
You don't want to lug bananas in the rain anyway, do you, Jackie? He reaches over and takes the tab back from Jackie.
Aah, give it to 'im. Terry hands the slip to Edie and adds, for the benefit of

Here you go, muscles. Nice wrastlin' with you. He flexes his forearm and throws two quick jabs at an ima opponent, a characteristic gesture. He sets his cap at a and winks at his chums but we feel his manner is forced, his guilt. Edie looks after him with smoldering anger. She turns as Father Barry comes into view, leading Pop. P bleeding and he is pretty thoroughly battered. Nolan join
Pop, you all right?
(brusquely)
Sure, just the beakВ— (taps his nose)
It's been busted before. Edie hands him the tab.
HereВ—I got it for you. Pop takes it, but he is humiliated, and bitter that she s in this moment of weakness.
Okay, I can use itВ— (glares at her)
Now go back to the Sisters where you belong. (His anger mounting with his need to regain

his self-respect, he turns on Father Barry.) I'm surprised with you, Father, if you don't mind my sayin' so. Lettin' her see things ain't fit for the eyes of a decent girl. Just then Big Mac shouts from the pier opening.
Hey, Doyle, you got a tab?
(holding it up angrily)
Yeah!
Then get in there. Number three gang, number one hatch, puh-ronto. Pop jumps and hurries.
(following Pop)
Our welfare officer. He's been away three times for assault and battery.

Watching him go. Around them are at least one hundred rej linger in resentful silence. Some of them are rubbing han the melee. A truck, hurrying into the pier, sounds its ho men barely avoid being run down.
(angrily, to the rejected group)
Outa the way. Come back tomorra. Father Barry looks at all this in amazement.
(to one rejected man)
What do you do now? The man shrugs, too beaten down to answer. Father Barry a What are you gonna do?
(bitterly)
Like he says. Come back tomorra. Luke goes along with Father Barry, who approaches Moose a have also been rejected.
Is this what you do, just take it like this?
(carefully looking around and lowering his voice matter-of-factly)
Five straight mornin's I been Standin' here and the bum looks right through me. There's always a couple hundred left standin' in the street.
(undertone)
Shh. Sonny's over there.
And there's nothing you can do? How about your union?
(in an undertone) You know how a blackjack
local works, Father. Get up in a meetin', make a motion, the lights go out, you go out.
If three guys talk on a corner, Johnny'sВ— (He takes a careful look around.)
В—boys break us up. Look at 'em.
Didn't the minersВ— sailorsВ— garment workersВ— get rid of this years ago?
The waterfront's tougherВ— like it ain't part of America. Anywhere else you got the law protectin' ya. Here ya just get knocked off and forgotten. LikeВ— (He stops.)
(frightened)
Shh, not here, across the street.
River Street, you might as well be inВ— Sonny and Truck move in.
What is this, a church picnic? Get outa here. Excuse me, Father. They all start away from the pier.
(looking to see if he is out of earshot)
That's how it's been ever since Johnny and his cowboys took over the local.
Name one place where it's even safe to talk.
(impulsively)
Use the church.
What?
(after a significant pause)
The bottom of the church. Father Barry has spoken in a normal voice,as contrasted w whispering of the others, and they all look off toward So to see if they have heard.
Watching them suspiciously.

head_text.subj: BACK TO FATHER BARRY, EDIE AND GROUP

text: (still in an undertone)
You know what you're letting yourself in for, Father?
Got a cigarette on you? (As he is given one, he looks off)
From Father Barry's angle.
(his voice decisive)
You heard me boys. Use the bottom of the church. Father Barry looks at Edie.
In this long area atop the working pier various articles stored. Elderly men work at a leisurely pace.
On top of which Terry is lying comfortably reading a comi Charley enters to him.
Working hard?
It's a living. He wriggles himself deeper into the coffee bags.
(looking up at him)
You don't mind working once in a while to justify this lofty position?
I just fnished work. I counted the bags.

We got a little extra detail for you. The local priest and this Doyle girl are getting up a meeting in the church. We'd like a rundown on it. You know, names and numbers of all the players. You're nominated.
(frowns)
Why me, Charley? I'd feel funny going in there.
(indicating this job)
Johnny does you favors, kid. You got to do a little one for him once in a while.
But going in that church, I'd be stooling for you, Charley. You make a pigeon out of me.
(tolerantly)
Let me explain you something, kid. Stooling is when you rat on your friends, on the guys you're with. (sees Terry frown)
When Johnny needs a favor, don't try to figure it out, just do it. Now go ahead, join the congregation.

This is an overflow chapel for the church above. There ar glass windows, an altar, pews and the figures of saints, utter simplicity; it has not lost its basement feeling, a unadorned walls and low lighting may suggest the catacomb The above is seen from the POV of Terry as he approaches. Barry faces a small group of longshoremen still in their including Nolan, Moose, Tommy, and Luke; Edie sits behind faced, rather ascetic-looking priest, FATHER VINCENT, sit disapprovingly in the rear. As Terry stands in the rear, enter, Father Barry is saying:
(rapidly, with a cigarette in his mouth)

I thought there'd be more of you here, butВ— the Romans found out what a handful could do, if it's the right handful. And the same goes for you and the mob that's got their foot on your neck. I'm just a potato-eater but isn't it simple as one - two thre OneВ— The working conditions are bad. TwoВ— They're bad because the mob does the hiring. ThreeВ— The only way to break the mob is to stop letting them get away with murder. (He looks around at them. Everybody is silent,
waiting.) If just one of you would answer one question, we'd have a start. (pause)
And that question isВ— Who killed Joey Doyle?

Silence. Moose looks down at the floor. Nolan works his l the palm of his right hand. Tommy runs his hand over his embarrassed. Luke stares straight ahead of him. Terry set stubbornly. Edie looks at all of them with a hopeful, ple intensity. Father Barry waits, and then asks againВ—

Not one of you has a line onВ— who killed Joey Doyle? Silence. I've got a hunch every one of you could tell us something about it. Silence. Then answer this oneВ— How can we call ourselves Christians and protect these murderers with our silence? Silence. The Father looks from one to the other, hoping f in the ranks. Terry starts down the aisle, just as Edie t
Tommy Collins, you were Joey's best friend. How can you just sit there and not be saying anything?
(miserably)
I'll always think of him as my best friend, butВ— He falls silent and shakes his head. Next to him, Nolan n
(muttering to Moose)
Who asked him here?
(to Terry)
Have a seat. I'm trying to find out just what happened to Joey Doyle. Maybe you can help. Terry is tight-lipped.
(whispering loudly to Moose)
The brother of Charley the Gent. They'll help us get to t bottom of the river.
(turnsaround angrily)
Keep Charley out of this.
(spunkily)
You don't think he'd beВ— helpful?
(insolently)
Go ask him, why don't you ? Ask him yourself.
Maybe I willВ— one of these days.
(laughs scornfully)
One of these days. They glare at each other. Edie regards Terry with curiosi
(cutting through)
Now listen, if you know who the pistols are, if you see them on the dock every day, are you going to keep still until they cut you down one by one? (turns from one to the other)
Are you? Are you? How about you, Nolan?
Father, one thing you got to understand. On the dock we've always been D 'n D.
(puzzled)
D 'n D?
(nodding)

Deef 'n dumb. Somethin' c'n happen right in front of our noses and we don't see nothin'. You know what I mean. No matter how much we hate the torpedoes we don't rat. Moose, Luke, and others mutter agreement.

Boys, get smart. I know you're Getting' pushed around but one thing we got in this country is ways of fightin' back. Getting' the facts to the public. Testifyin' for what you know is right against what you know is wrong. What's ratting to them is telling the truth for you. Can't you see that? (turns from one to another)
Huh? Huh? The men do not respond. A few look back at Terry apprehen Barry subsides, feeling defeated. Father Vincent comes fo takes over the meeting.
(dismissing them)

This seems to be just about all we can do at this time, I think you'll agree, Father, and so I'd like to close with a few words from St. Paul, "Come unto me... ." He is interrupted by the shattering of glass as a rock co through the long narrow stained-glass window. Everyone looks at each other Some jump up.
(thumbing toward the window)
That's our friends.
Looking at Edie; then he cases the room for other exits.
What did I tell you about sticking your neck out?
These fellers need help, Vince.
(striding off)
Okay. Don't blame me when they pack you off to Abyssinia.
I'll take my chances. (turnstoward the group, picking up the rock)
We must be on the right track or they wouldn't be sending us this little calling card. (pause)
Who's got a cigarette? (as he takes one)
You better go home in pairs. They all start out tensely, Father Barry helping to pair the door. Edie lingers behind them, frightened. As she st Terry suddenly approaches.
Not that way. She looks at him in surprise. Terry pulls her back with r solicitousness.
Come on, I'll get you out. Before she has time to protest he is leading her rapidly exit.

Moose and Nolan come down the steps of the church. They d they are being ambushed but the audience does. The goons them, and we see the effect of this action in the giant s the face of the church, the flailing bats looming as larg poles. We hear the cries of pain, then groans.

As Father Barry runs up, Sonny and Truck are working Nola baseball bats. Father Barry wrestles with them, taking a in consequence, and the goons take off. Nolan sinks to th with blood streaming from his head and Father Barry kneel
You all right, Nolan?
(furiously)
Yeah, considerin' they was usin' my head for a baseball!
(taking a handkerchief to blot the blood on
Nolan's face) Nice fellows.
(rubbing his head angrily)
Those blood suckers. How I'd love to fix those babies butВ—
But you still hold out for silence? Nolan hesitates.
You still call it ratting?
Are you on the level, Father?
What do you think?
If I stick my neck out, and they chopped it off, would that be the end of it? Or are you ready to go all the way?
I'll go down the line, Kayo, believe me.
Baseball batsВ— that's just for openers. They'll put the muscle on you, turned-around collar or no turned-around collar.
And I still say you stand up and I'll stand up with you.
Down to the wire?
So help me God!
Well, I had my fun, I've drunk my fill and I tickled some good-lookin' filliesВ— I'm on borried time. Nolan says this with a slight smile as he makes an effort
(as he helps Nolan to his feet with a grin)
We're off and running, Kayo.
Father Vincent is nervously closing the doors.

Leading down to a dark side street. Terry pulls Edie alon pace. He jumps down from the bottom landing, then looks u her, for whom the height is too great. He holds her for a he stops and listens. Heavy rapid footsteps approach. It Luke, closely followed by goons wielding baseball bats. T Edie back against the wall into the shadows. The goons run past and Terry starts racing with narrow alley in the opposite direction.
The one that meets the alley at the other end. As Terry r street with Edie, he looks around to be sure all's quiet.
(looking back)
I think we're O.K.
(catching her breath)
Thanks. (shakes her head)
Steel pipes and baseball bats.
They play pretty rough.
(puzzled)
Which side are you with?
(pointing to himself)
I'm with Terry.
(straightening her dress)
I'll get home all right now.
I better see you get there. She looks at him wonderingly. The rummy longshoreman, Mut shuffles over toward Edie with his hand out, frightening Terry.
A dime. One thin dime for a cup of coffee.
Coffee, that's a laugh. His belly is used to nothing but rotgut whiskey.
(ignoring Terry and coming closer to Edie)
One little dime you don't need. (He brings his whiskered, sodden face very close to Edie's and stares at her as if
througha dense fog.)
I know youВ— you're Edie Doyle. Your Brother's a saintВ— (crosses himself quickly)
В–only one ever tried to get me my compensation. He points a wavering (unconsciously accusing) finger at T
Remember, Terry, you was there the night he was'?
Looking at Terry in surprise.
(nervously reaching into his pocket)
Yeah, yeahВ— Here's half a buck, go have yourself a ball.
I can't believe itВ— a small fortune. (He kisses the coin, then pulls from his shirt a small tobacco pouchful of coins in which he deposits this one.) (then turns on
Terry again) You can't buy meВ— you're still a bum! (raises his cap to Edie with unexpected formality)
'Bye, Edie. Lord have mercy on Joey. (crosses himself quickly and he goes off)
(sourly)
Look who says bum!
(looking after Mutt)
Everybody loved Joey. From the little kids to the old rummies. (looks up at Terry)
Did you know him very well?
(evasively)
Everybody knew him. He got around.
(looking after Mutt)
What did that man mean when he said you were... .?
(quickly)
Aah, he's a bottlebaby, he talks to himself, the joke of the neighborhood.
(glancing at him and then hurrying her steps)
I better get home. She gives Terry as wide a berth as possible.
Don't be afraid of me. I ain't going to bite you. She continues to walk apart from him. What's the matter, they don't let you walk with fellers where you've been?
You know how the Sisters are.
You training to be a nun or something?
(smiles)
It's a regular college. It's just run by the nuns. The Sisters of St. Anne.
And you spend all your time just learning stuff, huh?
(smiling at the way he puts it)
I want to be a teacher.
A teacher! Dong!!! (He's impressed)
You know I admire brains. Take my brother Charley. He's very brainy. Very.
(quietly)
It isn't brains. It's how you use them.
(increasingly impressed, almost awestruck)
Yeah. Yeah. I get your thought. You know I seen you lots of times before. Parochial school on Pulaski Street? Seven, eight years ago? Your hair come down inВ—
In braids? That's right.
Looked like two pieces of rope. And your teeth wereВ—
(smiling)
I know. I thought I'd never get those braces off.
(laughs)
Man, you were a mess!
I can get home all right from hereВ—
The thought I'm tryin' to get over is you grew up beauteeful. Remember me?
(nodding)
The moment I saw you.
(strutting)
Some people got faces that stick in your mind.
(tenderly)
I remember you were in trouble all the time.
Now you got me! It's a wonder I wasn't punchy by the time I was twelve. The rulers those Sisters used to whack me with! (cracks himself on the head and laughs)
They thought they could beat an education into meВ—I foxe 'em.
Maybe they just didn't know how to handle you.
(warming to the subject)
How would you've done it?
With a little more patience and kindness. That's what makes people mean and difficult. Nobody cares enough about them. Terry plays "Hearts and Flowers" on an imaginary violin. curiously.
What's that?
Pardon me while I reach for my beads.
What?
What-what? Where you been the last four five years? Outer space?
When Mother died Pop sent me out to school in the country. He was afraid with no one home I'dВ— get into bad company.
(righteously)
Well he played it smart. Too many good-for-nothin's around here. All they got on their mind's a little beer, a little pool, a littleВ— (looks at her and catches himself, his face
registering: I'm with a Nice Girl)
I better get you home.
Overhead a flock of pigeons sweep by, close enough for th their wings to be heard. Terry and Edie approach the stoop.
(looking up)
Boy, they sure fly nice, don't they?
(surprised)
Do you like pigeons?
That's my own flock up there, getting their evening workout. I won plenty of races with 'em. (impulsively)
Listen, you want to see them? Come up on the roof with me and I'll show 'em to you. They have reached the stoop of Edie's tenement.
I'd better go in.
(not wanting to let go of her)
I only live up there and across the roof.
(going in)
Thanks anyway.
(following her)
Listen, Edie, am I going to see you again?
(simply)
What for?
(suddenly bewildered)
I don't know.
I really don't know. Then she goes in abruptly. Terry is left standing there, her, confused by the unfamiliar emotion he is feeling for his thoughts are interrupted byВ—
The sound of a lower- floor window opening as Mrs. Collin head out.
You got some nerve.
What do you mean?
Overhearing, as she enters the house.
You know what I mean. Leave her alone.
(apologetically)
I was only talkin' to her.
She's off limits for bums like you. Leave her alone.
I can look at her, can't I? It's a free country.
(as she goes)
Not that free. She closes window.
She mounts the stairs, thinking about what she has just h close on her face, as she approaches the door to their pl
As Edie enters, Pop, in his undershirt, favorite attire, putting the last articles into Edie's suitcase. He snaps shut. There is an old cat on the bed.
You're all packed. (reaches into his pocket)
And here's your bus ticket. You're on your way back to St. Anne's.
Pop, I'm not ready to go back yet.

Edie, for years we pushed quarters into a cookie jar, to keep you up there with the Sisters, and to keep you from things like I just seen out the window. My own daughter arm-in-arm with Terry Malloy. You know who Terry Malloy is?
(simply)
Who is he, Pop?
(mimics)

Who is he! Edie, you're so softhearted and soft-headed you wouldn't recognize the devil if he had you by the throat. You know who this Terry Malloy is? The kid brother of Charlie the Gent, Johnny Friendly's right hand, a butcher in a camel hair coat.
Are you trying to tell me Terry is too?
(shouting)
I'm not trying to tell you he's Little Lord Fauntleroy.
He tries to act tough, but there's a look in his eyes that... .

A look in his eyes! Hold your hats, brother, here we go again. You think he's one of those cases you're always draggin' in and feelin' sorry for. Like the litter of kittens you hadВ—the only one she wants to keep has six toes and it's cockeyed to boot. Look at him. The bum! And the crush you had on that little Abyssinian... .
He wasn't Abyssinian, Pop, Assyrian... .

Six-toed cats. Assyrians. Abyssinians. It's the same difference. Well don't think this Terry Malloy is any six-toed cockeyed Assyrian. He's a bum. Charley and Johnny Friendly owned him when he was a fighter and when they ring the bell he still goes into action.
(musing)
He wanted to see me again.
You think we kept you out in Tarrytown just to have you go walkin' with a corner saloon hoodlum like Terry Malloy? Now get back to Tarrytown, before I put a strap to you.
(flaring)

And learn about charity and justice and all the other things people would rather talk about than practice? Pop goes up to her and holds out his two arms, his right one closer to Edie; he trembles with emotion.

See this arm? It's two inches longer 'n the other one. That's years of workin' and sweatin', liftin' and swingin' a hook. And every time I heisted a box or a coffee bag I says to myselfВ—this is for Edie, so she can be a teacher or somethin' decent. I promised your mother. You better not let her down. Suddenly touched, Edie goes up to Pop and kisses him.
Pop, don't think I'm not feeling grateful for all you've done to get me an education and shelter me from this. (becoming aroused)

But now my eyes are open. I see things I know are so wrong how can I go back and keep my mind on things that are only in books and that people aren't living? I'm staying, Pop. And I'm going to keep on trying to find out who's guilty for Joey. I'd walk home with a dozen Terry Malloys if I thought they could help me. I tell you I'm staying, Pop. Pop starts to pull his belt out of his trousers.
You are likeВ—
(with regret and affection)
Pop! She turns and runs out. Pop with his belt in one hand, ta steps after her and then stops and stares at the unused b
(shaking his head as he mutters)
Jesus, Mary and Joseph, keep an eye on her.

Autumn on the roof. It is not particularly romanticВ—ther clotheslines, wooden boxes, etc. But to the people of thi it is a luxurious terrace. Terry's birds are aloft, flyin circle, nicely silhouetted against the sun-drenched eveni Conners is with him. Terry has a long pole with which he keeps the birds circl leaning against the wall, playing an Irish melody on his wife, a heavyset woman, sits beside him.
(Moving her feet)
My feet feels like dancin'. But the rest of me just feels like settin' here.
As he swings his pole he looks off and seesВ—
Hurrying toward him across the rooftops.
Catching sight of her, and stopping to admire her as she him.
(to Jimmy)
OkayВ— I guess they got enough exercise. Let 'em come in. He puts down the pole and the birds start flying down tow He sees Edie approach.
I wonder how long she's goin' to hang around, huh, Terry?
(indicating the pigeons)
Be sure they got enough water. And he turns to await Edie.
I changed my mind. I feel real mean tonight.
(pleased)
Good. So do I. As Jimmy goes off to fetch some water, Edie reads the fan on the back of his jacket.
The Golden Warriors.
I started them Golden Warriors. I was their first Supreme Commander. Now Jimmy starts back toward them.
My shadow. He follows me around like I was Mickey Mantle. Thinks I'm a big man because I boxed pro for a while. (throws a few quick jabs)
Several pigeons swoop down and enter the coop. He nods to
Here they come! The champion flock of the neighborhood.
You don't mind yourself at all, do you. (turns to the birds)
Joey used to race pigeons.
(darkening)
He had a few birds. (pauses, nods toward Joey's coop across the roof)
I got up and fed 'em this morning.
That was nice of you.
(disconcerted, needing to talk)
I like pigeons. You send a bird five hundred miles  away he won't stop for food or water until he's back  in his own coop.
I wouldn't have thought you'd be so interested В—in pigeons.
I go for this stuff. You know this city's full of hawks? There must be twenty thousand of 'em. They perch on top of the big hotels and swoop down on the pigeons in the park.
(slightly horrified)
The things that go on.
(proudly indicating a large pigeon in the coop)
How do you like that one?
Oh she's a beauty.
(critically)
She's a he. His name is Swifty.
My lead bird. He's always on that top perch.
He looks awful proud of himself.
Why shouldn't he? He's the boss.
If another fella tries to take that perch away from him, he lets him have it.
Even pigeons aren't peaceful.
One thing about them though, they're faithful. They get married just like people.
Better.
Yeah, once they're mated they stay together all their lives until one of 'em dies.
That's nice. They look at each other, both strangely upset.
(suddenly)
Listen, you like beer?
I don't know.
Want to go out and have one with me?
In a saloon?
(imploring)
Come on, I know a quiet one, with a special entrance for ladies... .
Perhaps a sign can emphasize Ladies' Entrance. As Terry l a tipsy Irish biddy is noisily protesting her enforced de
В—I'm only after havin' one more wee bitВ—

You and your one-mores. Now beat it. As Terry and Edie reach the bar, the radio blares a baseb roar goes up from the speaker. Bartender nods to Terry. I small well-oiled longshoreman sings "I'll Take You Home A Kathleen" in a plaintive, cracking voice.
Well, what do you knowВ—Jackie just stole home.
(glancing at Edie with a mischievous wink at the
bartender) I wouldn't mind doing that myself. The bartender grins. Terry guides Edie to a small table.
(to Edie)
What're you drinking? Edie hesitates, obviously not knowing what to ask for. A the bar says, loudlyВ—
Give me a Glockenheimer.
(it could be root beer for all she knows)
I'll try aВ— Glockenheimer.
(to bartender)
Likewise. And draw two for chasers. (to Edie)
Now you're beginning to live.
(as the drinks are poured)
I am? Edie picks up her glass, sniffs the contents with some di then sips it tentatively. Terry watches with amusement.
(still swaggering)
Not that wayВ— like this. (holds glass up)
Down the hatch! (gulps it down)
Wham! Edie takes her drink and does likewise. She gasps and her
(with soft amazement)
Wham... .
(grinning at her)
How do you like it?
It's quiteВ— (gulps)
В–nice.
How about another one?
(already feeling this one)
No thanks... .
(to bartender)
Hit me again, Mac.
(as he pours drink)
See the fight last night? That RileyВ—both hands. Little bit on your style.
Hope he has better luck.
Were you really a prize fighter?
(nods)
I went pretty good for a while, didn't I, Al? ButВ— I didn't stay in shapeВ— andВ— (a little ashamed)
В—I had to take a few dives.
A dive? You mean, into the water?
(laughs harshly)
Naw, in the ring, a dive is- He stops, shakes his head and with his finger draws an in in the air.
(mystified)
Now what are you doing?
Describing you. A square from out there. I mean you're nowhere. (draws it again)
Miss Four Corners.
(smiles, but persistent)
What made you want to be a fighter?

I had to scrap all my life. Figured I might as well get paid for it. When I was a kid my old man got killedВ—never mind how. Charley and I was put in a placeВ—they called it a Children's Home. Some home! I run away and peddled papers, fought in club smokers andВ— (catches himself)
But what am I runnin' off at the mouth for? What do you care?
Shouldn't we care about everybody?
What a fruitcake you are!
Isn't everybody part of everybody else?
Gee, thoughts! Alla time thoughts! (then)
You really believe that drool?
(deeply shocked)
Terry!
Want to hear my philosophy? Do it to him before he does it to you.
(aroused)
Our Lord said just the opposite.
I'm not lookin' to get crucified. I'm lookin' to stay in one piece.
(flaring up) I never met such a person. Not a
spark of romance or sentiment orВ— or human kindness in your whole body.
What do they do for you, except get in your way?
And when things get in your wayВ— or people В—you just knock them asideВ— get rid of ThemВ— is that your idea?
(defensiveВ— stung)
ListenВ— get this straightВ— don't look at me when you say them things. It wasn't my fault what happened to your brother. Fixing Joey wasn't my idea... .
(gently)
Why, Terry, who said it was?
(lamely)
Well, nobody, I guess. But that Father Barry, I didn't like the way he kept lookin' at me.
He was looking at everybody the same way. Asking the same question.
(troubled, not convinced)
Yeah, yeah... . (suddenly)
This Father Barry, what's his racket?
(shocked)
HisВ— racket?
(trying to regain his bravado)
You've been off in daisyland, honey. Everybody's got a racket.
But a priest...? With his finger he again describes a square in the air an through it to Edie. This time it angers her.
You don't believe in anything, do you?
